Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: The siblings are walking home from school together on a familiar street.
Expectation2: Ensure the safe and punctual operation of the subway train.
Situation2: A critical alert for a brake system malfunction has just appeared, requiring an immediate report and stop.
Story: I was walking home from school with my little brother, as we always did, chatting about his day and making sure he stayed close to the curb. My phone buzzed in my pocket—a critical alert from the subway control center. As a subway operator, I was on call for emergencies, and the message was urgent: a brake system malfunction on the train I was scheduled to operate in less than an hour. I was expected to report in immediately, assess the situation, and ensure the safety of hundreds of passengers. But right now, my brother was skipping ahead, laughing, and I knew I was supposed to keep him safe, especially with the busy intersection coming up. My mind raced, torn between the responsibility to protect my brother and the duty to prevent a possible disaster underground. I could feel the weight of both roles pressing down on me, each demanding my full attention, and I stood frozen on the sidewalk, heart pounding, caught between two worlds that needed me at the same time.
